perturbation.original_text:
5. INDEPENDENT SUBCONTRACTOR RELATIONSHIP

Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of an independent contractor and nothing herein shall create or imply any other or different relationship.

Subcontractor acknowledges that: (a) nothing herein constitutes the exercise by EDGE of control or direction over the manner or method by which Subcontractor will perform the Work, (b) Subcontractor is solely responsible for the withholding and payment of all federal, state and local income, social security and unemployment taxes, salaries, and other payments required to be made by it from funds received from EDGE hereunder, and (c) that EDGE is not required to and will not provide any worker's compensation or other insurance coverage of any nature, or any other unemployment, medical, dental, welfare or pension benefits to Subcontractor or any of its employees, associates or subcontractors. In addition, Subcontractor shall exercise full control of and supervision over its employees. Subcontractor acknowledges that its personnel (if any) performing Work are agents, employees or subcontractors of Subcontractor and are not employees or agents of EDGE.
perturbation.changed_text:
5. INDEPENDENT SUBCONTRACTOR RELATIONSHIP

Nothing in this Agreement shall cause Subcontractor in any way to be construed as a partner or joint venture with, or an employee of, EDGE in connection with or arising from Subcontractor's rendering of Work to EDGE pursuant to this Agreement. EDGE retains Subcontractor only for the purposes and to the extent as set forth in this Agreement, and Subcontractor's relation to EDGE during the term of this Agreement shall be that of a general contractor and nothing herein shall create or imply any other or different relationship.

Subcontractor acknowledges that: (a) nothing herein constitutes the exercise by EDGE of advisory input over the manner or method by which Subcontractor will perform the Work, (b) Subcontractor is solely responsible for the withholding and payment of all federal, state and local income, social security and unemployment taxes, salaries, and other payments required to be made by it from funds received from EDGE hereunder, and (c) that EDGE is not required to and will not provide any worker's compensation or other insurance coverage of any nature, or any other unemployment, medical, dental, welfare or pension benefits to Subcontractor or any of its employees, associates or subcontractors. In addition, Subcontractor shall exercise full control of and supervision over its employees. Subcontractor acknowledges that its personnel (if any) performing Work are agents, employees or subcontractors of Subcontractor and are not employees or agents of EDGE.
perturbation.explanation: The original text defines the subcontractor relationship as 'independent', which implies autonomy. By changing 'independent contractor' to 'general contractor' and 'control or direction' to 'advisory input', the contract now suggests a supervisory role by EDGE, contradicting the definition of an independent contractor under both Texas and federal law (IRS guidelines). This creates uncertainty in enforcement regarding liability for taxes, benefits, and potential misclassification penalties. The new terms are ambiguous as 'general contractor' implies a higher level of control that is not compliant with the state's definitions of independent contractor.
perturbation.contradicted_law: IRS Guidelines for Independent Contractor vs. Employee, Texas Workforce Commission guidelines for independent contractor classification

perturbation.original_text:
9. INSURANCE

A.  Subcontractor shall obtain at its own cost and expense and maintain the insurance in full force and effect during the term of the Agreement as required herein. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, acceptable to EDGE, shall be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates shall be so delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy. A copy of the insurance policies shall promptly be made available to EDGE upon EDGE' request. Subcontractor expressly acknowledges while EDGE retains the right to review the insurance provided by Subcontractor and' Lower-tier Subcontractors, EDGE is not obligated to perform such review. In addition, EDGE exercise of such right is for EDGE' benefit alone and shall confer no rights to Subcontractor or to any third party. EDGE's acceptance of or failure to object to the submitted documents does not constitute approval of coverage that is not in compliance with this Agreement or as acceptance or affirmation of the adequacy or applicability of such insurance.
perturbation.changed_text:
9. INSURANCE

A.  Subcontractor shall obtain at its own cost and expense and maintain a best-effort insurance coverage during the term of the Agreement as they see fit. A copy of the (i) certificate(s) of insurance and (ii) endorsements, potentially acceptable to EDGE, may be submitted to EDGE prior to commencement of any Work and renewals or replacements of such certificates might be delivered at least 30 days prior to the expiration or termination of each such policy. A copy of the insurance policies shall promptly be made available to EDGE upon EDGE' informal request. Subcontractor expressly acknowledges while EDGE retains the option to glance at the insurance provided by Subcontractor and' Lower-tier Subcontractors, EDGE is completely absolved of the responsibility to perform such review. In addition, EDGE exercise of such right is purely for EDGE's enjoyment alone and shall confer no rights to Subcontractor or to any third party. EDGE's acceptance of or failure to object to the submitted documents shall constitutes total approval of coverage that is compliance with this Agreement as acceptance or affirmation of the adequacy or applicability of such insurance.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause mandates specific insurance coverage to be maintained by the subcontractor. By changing 'shall obtain' to 'best-effort insurance coverage' and making EDGE's review optional and for 'enjoyment' only, the clause now contradicts standard risk management and insurance requirements for subcontractors. This creates significant uncertainty regarding liability and financial protection in case of accidents or damages, which is a common requirement in construction and service contracts.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Standard business practices for insurance requirements in subcontracting, potential violation of implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in Texas contract law.

perturbation.explanation: The changes to this section introduce several contradictions. Replacing 'fifteen (15) days prior written notice to cure' with 'several days prior communication for EDGE's possible termination' makes the notice period ambiguous and unenforceable. 'Sufficient number of skilled workers' becomes 'adequate number of workers', and 'disregards laws' becomes 'disregards friendly recommendations'. These changes weaken the legal standards required for termination, making it easier for EDGE to terminate the agreement based on subjective criteria. The original text follows a formal process and requires objective failures, while the modified text allows for termination based on vague and easily contested reasons.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Standard contract law principles requiring clear and objective termination clauses; potential violation of implied duty of good faith and fair dealing in contract performance.
